Your argument is most interesting. Especially fascinating in that it appears to be a deductive argument. As I recast it in informal-logic terms, you've argued thus (as one of several ways of stating your argument)...
 
 Premise #1...God is a God of love and justice, and thus does not make one group of persons suffer for another group's deeds.
 
 Premise #2...The 2nd law of thermodynamics (including its results of death, sickness, etc.), which applies throughout the universe, is the consequence of Adam's Fall.
 
 Premise #3 (for the reductio)...A group of aliens exists off the earth.
 
 Intermediate Conclusion #4...Being in the universe and subject to the 2nd Law, that group of aliens suffers as the result of another group's deeds.
 
 Contradictory Conclusion #5...A group of persons suffers for another's deeds BUT no group of persons suffers for another's deeds--CONTRADICTION.
 
 Therefore #6...No such aliens exist.
 
 * * * 
 
 What an interesting argument! Whether or not SOUND, it's certainly VALID, deductively.
 
 No less interesting is your statement that, were aliens discovered, you'd have to "seriously question your belief." More particularly, what you'd have to do is falsify at least one of Premise #1 or Premise #2.
 
 Fortunately, the hypothesis that aliens exist is partially testable. All you have to do is wait. If we never, ever find any, then perhaps you're right. If we do find some, then you're definitely mistaken.
 
 Keep me posted, won't you?
 
 Bradley
